p.seg: The mind is the basis for manifestation
the mind is noble, the mind disposes.
If in one's mind one thinks bad thoughts
and thus speaks, and thus acts,
then the bitter results of this misdeed will naturally pursue one
in the manner of carts passing through their rut.
The mind is the basis for manifestation
the mind is noble, the mind disposes.
If in one'smind one thinks good thoughts
and then speaks accordingely, and then acts accordingly,
then good fortune and joy will naturally pursue one,
like a shadow following a shape.
If one acts following confused thought
one is constricted to stupidity and enters darkness;
when one is self-aggrandising, without the Buddhist Way,
how can one unravel and understand good words?
If one acts following proper thoughts
then one will open up, will be enlightened;
one will not act on envy,
and nimbly one will understand properly good words.
He who bears a grudge against the resentment of others,
will never be without such resentment by others;
not to bear a grudge, to naturally cut oneself off from it,
this way may be taken as the ultimately important truth.
Do not indulge in blaming others,
make it your business to reflect on your own person;
if you have understood how to do this
you will be extinguished (into Nirvana) and be without troubles.
In your action show that your person is pure.
If you do not restrain your senses
if in drinking and eating you are not moderate,
if you are lazy and chicken-livered-weak,
if you are controlled by wickedness of mind,
then you are like the grass bent by the wind.
If you observe the impurities of your person
and you can restrain your senses,
if in eating you know how to be moderate
and you always enjoy making spiritual progress,
if you are not moved by motives of wickedness,
then you are like a large mountain (standing firm) in the wind.
One who does not vomit the poisons within,
Whose craving mind races about,
Who has not tamed himself;
should not dress the Buddhist way.
One who is able to vomit the poisons within,
who can admonish/constrain his mind and remain tranquil,
who subdues the mind and has controlled it,
this person should dress the Buddhist way.
If you take the genuine/true to be fake,
if you take the fake to be true,
this is an evil strategy,
and you will not gain the profit that comes from what is genuine and true.
If you understand what is genuine/true and practise what is true,
if when you see the fake you understand that it is fake,
then this is the right strategy
and you are sure to gain the benefit that comes from what is genuine/true.
Surely, when a roof is not water-tight
then when it is raining, it will leak;
when one's thinking is not mindful of one's actions
then lust will find its way into (one's mind)
Surely, when the roof is nicely watertight
when it is raining then it won't leak;
when you constrain your thoughts and you are mindful of your actions,
then indulgence will not arise.
When a vulgar person influences someone else
this is like (that person) getting close to a stinking object;
he will get increasingly confused and will get used to doing the wrong things,
he will fail to become enlightened and will become wicked.
When a person of moral worth influences another person
it is as if (that person) gets close to a perfume;
he will enter wisdom and practise goodness
and his actions will bring about a pure fragrance.
If one creates troubles, then afterwards one will have troubles,
if one does evil then the two parties (the doer and the one who suffers the injustice) will have troubles;
that person who has troubles will think fearful thoughts
and seeing the crimes (he commits) his mind will be full of fear.
When one creates joy one will afterwards be joyful,
and when one does good then both parties will be pleased;
when that other person is joyful one will only think of this pleasure
seeing the good fortune one's mind will be at ease.
If now you have (reason for) regret, then later you will have (reason for) regret.
If you do evil, then both parties (you, the offender and the person you offend against) have (reason for) regret:
your action lead to your own misfortune,
and the person who received the injustice will suffer anxieties.
If now you are pleased you will be pleased later,
and if you do good both parties (the agent as well as the recipient) will be pleased,
your acting will be of spiritual aid to yourself
you will receive good fortune, and you will be full of delight.
If you polish your rhetoric and are full of cravings,
if you are profligate and uncontrolled,
if you harbour indecent desires, anger and foolishness,
if you are not mindful of what arrests your regard,
if you join the common crowd as in a herd of cows,
then you are not a disciple of the Buddha.
If you speak at the proper times, and if you seek few things,
if you practise the Way in accordance with the Law,
if you remove all indulgence, anger, and foolishness,
if you wake up to what is correct and unravel/understand it in your thinking,
then, as such, you are a disciple of the Buddha.

div.head:
放逸品《法句經》第十有二十章
[The purpose of] this chapter on "Heedfulness" [Wantonness CH]

p.seg: [The purpose of] this chapter on "Heedfulness" [Wantonness CH]
is to help us restrain from sensuality by drawing on material connected with dicipline (vinaya).
It is to help us avoid doing evil and examine our faults.
By [pointing out] the Way,it exhorts us to be virtuous.
The ethical life is the Way to immortality;
Heedlessness is the Path to death
Those without craving never die;
To lose the Way is to lose one's life. (1)
The wise excels in guarding the Way (2)
And never becomes heedless.
Not craving, one attains to happiness;
From whence the bliss of attainment (3) is obtained (4).
One should constantly devote to meditation,
Be firm, and persevere in the proper course.
The strong ones can [thus] transcend existence,
And [attain Nirvana], the Supremely Auspicious (5). [There is no auspiciousness greater than that. CH]]
One who always gives rise to right mindfulness,
And whose actions are pure; his evil will easily eradicated,
Self-restrained, living by Dharma,
not transgressing (6) he earns a good name that spread afar (7).
Bringing forth effort and being heedful, .
Restraining himself and taming his mind,
The wise makes an illuminator (8) [for himself],
And does not return to the sea of darkness (9)
It is difficult to understand the fools' mind;
It is greedy, scattered and delights in disputes
The intelligent man values caution,
And protects it as his precious wealth (10).
Do not crave or delight in disputes, .
And do not indulge in sensual pleasure.
He who practises meditation and heedfulness,
Can gain great happiness (11)
To be heedless is like to be self-imprisoned. [inhibiting oneself CH]
He who realizes this is a noble one. [get rid of this uncontrolled extravagance CH]
Who has ascended to wisdom's mansion,
Free from danger, truly safe.
Such a wise man looks down upon the foolish,
Like [one] on the mountain and [the other] on the ground.
Upright amindst the chaotic, remains upright,
One is uniquely awakened.
Such a man's power surpasses a lion's.
Abandoning evil, he becomes the Greatly Wise (13).
By drowsiness, heavy as a mountain
The deluded one is covered (14).
Lying down comfortably, he ackowledges no suffering,
And hence enters the womb again and again (15).
There can be no occasion for self-indulgence; [If one does not practise constant self-indulgence... CH???]
He who is well-restrained can exhaust the cankers.
The moment when one indulges, Mara gets his chance,
Like a lion (waiting) to catch the deer (16).
He who has no self-indulgence,
Is a disciplined bhiksu.
He, whose thoughts are well calmed
Should constantly guard mind (17).
A bhiksu finds happiness (18) in caution;
Heedlessness gives him much worries.
Changing disputes from small to big,
And accumulating evil, he gets himself into fire (10).
The precept observance is meritious and brings happiness;
Transgressing the precepts produces fear at heart.
Destroying the cankers of the three spheres.
One comes close to Nirvana (20).
If one was heedless earlier,
But regains self-control later
- Such a one illumines the world.
Being mindful, he is focussed on proper [actions] (21)
If one made mistakes in doing evil,
But later covers over it by doing good
-Such a one illumines the world.
Being mindful, he becomes skillful in proper [actions] (22)
If one abandons the homelife when young and strong .
To vigourously practise the Buddha's teaching
-Such a one illumines the world,
Like the moon freed from clouds (23)
If one previously had committed evil
But later stops and commits no more;
-Such a one illumes the world,
Like the moon freed from clouds.
He who when living does naught to cause suffering,
And at death does not grieve;
Has seen the Truth (25), and is fearless.
He feels no sorrow where [others] do (26).
He who can illiminate the black dharmas,
And trains only in the pure white ones;
Will cross over the deep water, never to return.
He moves about with no attachment (27),
Unsullied by [sensual] pleasure,
With no craving, and no sorrow (28).

div.head:
心意品《法句經》第十一十有二章
心意品者， The chapter on 'Mind'

p.seg: The chapter on 'Mind'
explains that though the mind
is empty [of material substance] and formless,
its activities are endless.
Mind rushes to echoes, (1) (read: 駛作響 with Ming and Qing editions)
It is difficult to guard, to restrain.
The wise straightens its base, (2)
And its brightness then becomes great. (3)
[Mind] is fickle, hard to take care of (5) Fickleness is hard to keep firm control of CH)
It complies with every desire.
To subdue the mind is excellent
One's mind tamed, there will be calm. (6)
Mind is subtle, difficult to discern;
It moves according with craving.
The wise always protects his own mind;
When it is guarded, there will be peace (7)
[Mind] travels alone, going far off,
Is concealed and incorporeal;
Those who restrain (8) this mind, drawing near the Way
Will be released from Mara's bonds. (10)
If the mind does not settle down,
Or know the Dharma;
And is deluded in worldly affairs;
There will be no proper understanding (11)
Thoughts do not stop where they should;
They are ceaseless and endless. (12)
Meritorious actions can halt evil,
He who is aware [of this] is noble. (13)
Though the mental events taught by Buddha,
Are subtle and not [ultimately] real;
One must beware of the indulgent thoughts,
And not let mind go as it likes. (14)
Seeing the Dharma, one is happiest.
One's aims will be fulfilled.
The wise guards the subtle thoughts,
And break the causal conditions for suffering. (15)
The body cannot be had for long,
It will return completely to the ground;
Body decayed and consciousness departed -
What can one covet as a boarder therein? (16) (Since one lives in one's body for a limited time...CH)
The mind strives to (17) build dwelling places,
To come and go endlessly.
[If] one's thoughts are mostly devious,
One incurs troubles (18) for oneself. (19)
It is one's own mind which causes [suffering]
Not one's father or mother.
One must then work hard to align with the right,
And not turn back from meritorious actions. (20)
Conceal the six [senses] like a tortoise. (21)
Guard the mind like [the army guarding] the capital, (guard against wild thoughts like a city wall CH)
Fight Mara with wisdom; (The wise fights Mara CH)
And if victorious, there will be no more trouble. (22)

div.head:
華香品《法句經》第十二十有七章
華香品者， The chapter on 'Flower Fragrance'

p.seg: The chapter on 'Flower Fragrance'
aims at making clear that whatever one has learnt must be put into practice;
that because of the flower, the fruit is seen;
that one should turn falsehood into truthfulness.
Who can select (1) the land (2).
Leaving hells(read 監"prison>hell(???)) (3) behind and preferring heavens?
Who [can] speak the words of Dharma (4),
Like picking (1) the good flowers (5)?
A trainee can select the land,
Leaving hells behind and preferring heavens.
He speaks well the Words of Dharma
And can pick flowers of virtues (7).
He who knows worldly phenomena as earthenware,
Illusory, and coming abruptly into excistence;
Will break the blooming of Mara's flowers (8),
And see no more of the lord of death (10).
He who sees the body to be foam,
And all phenomena to be illusory by nature
Will break the blooming of Mara's flowers,
And see no more of the lord of death (10).
When the body is sick, it withers away,
Like the wilting flowers.
When death befalls one,
It dashes like rapids (11).
He who is insatiate in desires,
His mind becomes distracted.
Amassing wealth through evil means,
He makes an attack on himself (12).
As a bee gathers [honey from] flowers,
Without disturbing their colour and fragrance,
Taking away only their taste
likewise do the sages (13) enter the village (14)
Do not seek to observe others
As to what they have or have not done;
Always make self-reflexion
To know one's rights and wrongs (15)
As a flower pleasing to the mind,
With good colour but no fragrance;
Likewise are fine (16) words
Which if not practised yield no gain (17).
As a flower pleasing to the mind,
With beautiful colour as well as fragrance;
Likewise are fine (18) words
Which if practised yield blessings (18).
If one gathers (19) many precious flowers,
The garlands (20) made will be of distinguished beauty,
[Likewise] if one accumulates much virtues,
One's station of birth will change for the better (22).
Distinguished (23) plants and scented flowers,
Do not perfume against the wind;
Those close to the blooming of Enlightenment (24).
- The virtuous - diffuse frangrance in all directions (25)
Sandal wood and various scented substances (16)
Blue lotus, fragrant flowers
- [Their fragrance] though said to be real,
Is inferior to the fragrance of morality (27).
The fragrance of flowers is faint;
It cannot be called real.
The fragrance of ethical alignment
Reaches up to the heavens- It is excellent (28)
Those who are perfect in morality,
Whose actions are not heedless,
And who are freed through a concentrated mind (29)
Is far apart from Mara's path (30).
As in a field-ditch (31)
Near the main road,
A lotus could bloom,
Fragrant, clean and charming (32).
Likewise, in the cycle of rebirth (33)
Amidst the [lowest] end of worldlings (34),
The wise ones delight in going forth (35),
To be disciples of the Buddha (36).

div.head:
愚闇品《法句經》第十三二十有一章
愚闇品者， The aim of this chapter on 'The Fool'

p.seg: The aim of this chapter on 'The Fool'
is to clear up the blurred vision [of the fool]
Therefore, herein is described the situation where they find themselves in,
so that a glimpse into it, they may gain some insight [of their own folly]
For the wakeful the night is long.
For the weary, a journey is long.
For the fools, the cycle of rebirths is long,
Not knowing the True Dharma (1).
The fool's deluded mind is always in darkness,
Flowing on like a river.
It's better to fare on singly [than go with fools],
Alone with no companions (2).
Falling into the company of fools (3)
leads to sorrow for long.
Living with fools is painful,
Like being at enmity with oneself (4)
"I have sons, I have wealth"
So thinking, the fool is perturbed.
When even the self is not of one's own,
Whence (5) sons and wealth? (6)
"In summer I shall stay here;
In winter I shall stay here" (7)
Thus is the fool always apprehensive,
Not knowing the changes in the future (8).
The fool, ignorant of his extreme folly,
Claims himself to be wise.
Being foolish and yet [claiming] to excel (8) the wise
-This is foolishness to the extreme (10).
A fool's association with the wise
Is like a ladle [being unable] to taste,
Though he has taken liberties with (11) [the wise] for long,
He still remains ignorant of the Dharma (12).
An intelligent man's assocciation with the wise
Is like the tongue tasting the flavour;
Even if he just learns for a moment,
He understands at once the essence of the Way (13).
A fool performs actions
To incur troubles for himself.
With a happy mind he does evil,
Causing great sorrow [in future] (14).
The kind of action is not good,
Which receding from it one will regret;
With tears in the face
[To receive] the fruit from one's past practice (15).
The kind of action is virtous and good,
Which one will review happily;
Being sure to receive good results,
One is smilingly pleased with the practice (16).
So long as a past evil has not ripened, (no past!CH)
The fool is calm and at ease.
When the time (17) comes for it to ripen,
He will experience much affliction (18).
The fool, looking from where he is,
Sees not that he's heading towards suffering.
When he is about to fall into adversity,
He'll then realize that it's not good (19).
When a foold does evil,
He realizes not [its consequence].
Troubles chase after him and he will burn himself
- By his own evil, he is set ablaze (20)
The fool covets good food'
Month after month his nourishment increases.
Yet he is not even worth one-sixteenth.
Of one who has comprehended the Dharma (21).
The mental preoccupation of a fool
Will never yield any benefit.
He is [only] incurring punishment for himself; (22)
And retribution [is certain] - it has a seal (23).
One recognizes a fool by observing his situation:
He gives not but seeks much;
Where he falls into, there is no virtue or wisdom,
But very often, evil deeds (24).
Those away from the Way and close to craving,
Are [ordained] for food and for a name as a trainee.
As they are greedy and cling to the household,
They abundantly take offerings [from] other clans (25).
Don't aspire ambivalently as a trainee:
Don't be a householder-renunciate
Coveting the household goes against the Holy Teaching;
And by so doing one will make oneself destitute (26).
To do so is to be on a par with fools,
And it only increases one's craving and conceit
-The aspiration for gain is one thing;
The wish for Nirvana (27) is another (28).
Therefore, the knowledgeable ones
Should go forth to be the Buddha's disciples.
Leaving behind lust and worldly practices,
He'll never get trapped in the cycle of rebirth (29).

div.head:
明哲品《法句經》第十四
The chapter on 'The Wise'

p.seg: The chapter on 'The Wise'
recommends the wise practitioners,
to practise meritorious actions and make advance on the Path,
taking the Dharma as the bright mirror.
He who deeply examines good and evil,
Knows at heart what to fear and shun.
[Thus] fearing, he does not transgress,
And there will always be happiness (1) and no sorrow.
He who has merit from his previous life,
Should mindfully continue his [good] practices.
Goodness brings realization to his wishes,
And his good fortune will increase (3).
Believe in goodness and make merit.
Be not tired of accumulation [good] practices.
Believe and know that there is effect of good deed.
Eventually, [all] will be clear.
Always avoid unprofitable (5) [company].
Do not be close to the fools.
Think of following the good friends.
Associate with the noble ones (6).
He who finds joy (7) in Dharma sleeps well,
With a happy an clear mind.
The Dharma expounded by the Noble,
The wise always delights in practising (8).
The virtuous and wise ones,
Observe precepts and follow the Way;
Like the moon amidst stars,
They illumine the world(9).
Fletchers shape (10) the horns,
Navigators shape their boats.
Carpenters shape the wood,
The wise ones shape themselves (11).
Just as a thick rock
Is unmoved by wind;
The mind of the wise is heavy enough
Not to be upset by praise or blame (12).
Just as a deep pond
Is limped and clear;
The wise, having heard the Dharma
Becomes clear in his mind and happy (13).
The great man has in his nature no craving,
Every where he shines forth brightly.
Though encoutering now pleasure now pain,
He does not loftily show off his wisdom (14)
The virtous one has no worldly engeagement;
He desires neither sons nor wealth nor land.
Always morallay conscious, wise and righteous (15),
He covets not material success by unjust means (16).
The wise one knows that when one wobbles,
It is like a tree planted in sand.
If amidst friends, one's mind is not yet firm,
One gets tainted in accordance with their colours (17).
The world is immersed in the sea;
Few can cross over to the [other] shore.
If there is anyone
Wishing to cross, he must run fast (18).
Those who sencerely desire the Truth (19)
Accept the True Teaching
- This is being near the Other Shore;
It is best to be liberate from death (20).
He who cuts off the five aggregates (21),
Contemplative and wise,
Does not return to the deep sea.
Abandoning clinging (22) - this is being wise (23).
He who controls his passions,
Giving up pleasure, and craving for naught (24),
Can cone to rescue himself
From his sullied (25) mind - this is being wise (26).
Those who train to obtain right knowledge,
Who contemplate on true Enlightenment (27),
Who accept Thruth with one mind,
Who delight in not grasping (28),
Whose cankers and conditionings are detroyed
-Such persons have transcended the world (29).

div.head:
羅漢品《法句經》第十五有十章
The chapter on 'The Arahat'

p.seg: The chapter on 'The Arahat'
explains the nature of the true men [i.e.the arahats]:
He is free from craving and without attachment.
His mind does not change [inspite of worldly circumstances].
Those whose mind is pure and are mindful,
Delighting in nowhere;
Have crossed the sea of delusion,
Like swans who have abandoned their lake (4).
Those who eat according to the stomach's capacity,
Who accumulate nothing,
Whose mind is empty and markless (5);
Have passed the various stages of progress
Like the birds in the sky
Which can go far unhindered (6).
Those who have exhausted the world's conditioning (7)
Who are no more hung up with food;
Whose mind is empty and sorrow-free (8),
Have reached the state of emancipation.
They are [unattached] like flying birds
Which land temporarily only to fly away (9).
He whose senses are controlled, according with calm (10)
Like horses well tamed,
Who has abandoned conceit and the conditioning (11);
Is respected by the gods (12).
Without resentment, like the earth;
Immovable, like a mountain;
The true men are taintless,
And have ended the worldly cycle of rebirths (13).
His mind is already at rest,
His words and deed too are tranquil (14).
By right understanding he is freed;
Calmly, he goes into appreasement (15).
He who has given up craving and is detached
Who has broken the hindrances of the three spheres,
And whose desires are annihilated
- Is indeed a superior man (16).
Be it in village or in forest,
Or on the plains or high lands.
- Wherever the arahats (17) pass by
It cannot but become blessed (18).
He finds delight in the wilderness (19)
Which the worldlings do not;
Happy indeed are the unattached
Who seek no sensual pleasure (20).

div.head:
述千品《法句經》第十六十有六章
The chapter on 'The thousands'

p.seg: The chapter on 'The thousands'
explains that in one's training,
it is better [to learn a few scriptures] which are concise and clear
than having many scriptures without significance.
Though one might recite thousand words (1);
If their meanings be improper,
It's better to recite one with essential [meaning]
Hearing which thoughts will come to cease (2).
Though one might recite a thousand chapters,
What's the use if they be meaningless?
It's better to recite one with meaning,
Hearing and practising which one crosses over (4).
Though one might recite many sutras,
What's the use if one does not understand?
[It's better] to understand one dharma verse (5),
Practising which one may attain Enlightenment (6).
Battling with thousands and thousands of men,
One man might be the victor,
But he who conquers himself is better
He is indeed the greatest in the battle (7).
Best indeed is one who has conquered himself
He is as such called the King of men
Guarding his thoughts and training his self,
He restrains himself till the end (8).
Even the gods, said to be exalted,
Or demigods or Mara or Brahma or Sakya,
None of them can defeat
A man who has conquered himself (9).
One might each month offer sacrifices by the thousand,
And continue doing so for one's whole life;
This is not as good as, for a single moment
Recollecting the Dharma with one-mindedness
The merit produced by one such thought
Excels that of [offering sacrifice] for a whole life (10).
Though for a whole century,
one might attend to the sacrificial fire;
It's better, even if for a single moment,
To make offerings to the Three Honoured Ones
The merit of one such offering
Excels that of a century-long [sacrificial act] (11).
If one offers sacrifice to gods, for the merit's sake,
And subsequently espects reward from it;
This would not amount to a fourth [the merit]
From paying respect to the virtuous ones (12).
In him who properly conforms to etiquette
And always respects the elders.
Four blessings automatically increase;
Beauty, strength, long-life and happiness (13).
If one lives a hundred years,
Away from [mental] rectitude and unethical;
It's better to live a single day
Being ethical, mentally rectified and meditative (14).
If one lives a hundred years
Crooked, insincere and without wisdom;
It's better to live a single day
With a concentrated mind and acquiring true wisdom (15).
If one lives a hundred years
Sluggishly and without diligence;
It's better to live a single day,
Doing one's best and with diligence (16).
If one lives a hundred years
Without perceiving the rise and fall of things;
It's better to live a single day,
Perceiving [that] subtlety and knowing what to shun (17).
If one lives a hundred years
Without seeing the Path (18) of Ambrosia;
It's better to live a single day
Tasting-practising-the flavour of Ambrosia (19).
If one lives a hundred years
Without knowing the great Righteousness (20).
It's better to live a single day
Studying the essentials of the Budddha's dharma (21).

div.head:
惡行品《法句經》第十七二十有二章
The chapter on 'Evil Deeds'

p.seg: The chapter on 'Evil Deeds'
aims at converting the evil men.
[It explains that everything thought] stirred up [in the mind] will yield retribution.
If one does not do [any evil], one will be free from misfortune.
He who does not follow suit on seeing good done,
Will reverse to follow his evil mind,
He who does not seek to make merit properly
Will reverse to delight in sexual misconduct (9).
The ordinary worldlings, when doing evil,
Are not aware themselves of [the danger involved] (2).
Being foolish, they find pleasure in it,
And thereby accumulate poison for the future (3).
When a bad man does vices,
He gets submerged in them again and again,
Doing them with joyful desires.
He receives accordingly the retribution of his evil (4).
When a good man does virtuous deeds
[His virtues] increase progressively.
Doing them with a willing mind,
He receives accordingly the retribution of his merit (3).
[Though] the evil man might see as merit
His evil, while it has not ripened;
When his evil ripens,
He will experience the result of his evil (6).
[Though] the virtous man might see as evil
His good deed, while it has not ripened;
When his good deed ripens
He will experience the blessing (7).
He who strikes others will be struck.
He who hates others will be hated.
He who abuses others will be abused.
He who is angry with others will get anger (8).
The worldlings have no learning,
And do not understand the True Dharma.
Our life here is short;
How is it proper to do evil (9)?
Do not regard a tiny evil lightly,
Thinking that it will bring no troubles.
Water drops, though very tiny,
Gradually fill up a big vessel:
An evil is filled up,
Bit by bit, to its accomplishment (10).
Do not regard a tiny good lightly,
Thinking that it will bring no merit
Water drops, though very tiny
Gradually fill up a big vessel:
A merit is filled up,
By accumulating from the very tiniest.
When a man performs an action
Wether it be a good or evil one,
It is in each case for himself,
And [its effect] is not obliterated at death (12).
He who is fond of taking [others'things]
May think that there's nothing wrong with it;
[But] if you take things belonging to others
Others will also take your things (13).
Evil done does not immediately [bear fruits];
As in milking (14) a cow,
Its retribution awaits in the nether world,
As a fire concealed beneath ashes (15).
One may laugh in doing an evil;
[But] having (16) done it personally,
One will cry in experiencing its retribution,
When following one's action, the result of evil comes (17).
Doing evil, [the fool] does not rise up (18),
As if he has been blocked by an army.
On being dragged along, he then realizes,
That he has fallen into evil practice (19).
He subsequently suffers the result,
Of what he has done earlier (20).
Like poison being rubbed into a wound
Like a ship getting into an eddy,
When evil deeds multiply
They do harm to all (21).
He who falsely accuses one
Who is pure and unsullied
Harm will bounce back to this fool,
Like dust thrown against the wind (22).
Committing a mistake is not [necessarily] evil (23).
It becomes good when one repents subsequently.
Such a person illuminates the world,
Like the unclouded sun (24).
Wharever act a man has done (25),
He will himself witness [the result]:
A good act yields good [result].
A evil act yields bad [result] (26).
The consciousness of some (27) enter the womb:
The Evil ones are born in hells;
The doers of good (28) ascend to heavens.
Those unattached to existence attain nirvana (29)
Neither in the sky, nor mid-ocean,
Nor hiding places in the mountains and rocks
No place is to be found here
To escape the misfortune resulting from evil deed (30).
All beings are [similarly] afflicted:
Not being able to escape old age and death.
Only the kind and wise [are spared],
Not being bent on wrong and evil like others (31).

div.head:
刀杖品《法句經》第十八十有四章
The chapter on 'Knives And Rods'

p.seg: The chapter on 'Knives And Rods'
has the aim of teaching the practice of compassion
[[[using knives and rods.
- Not to harm sentient beings
All are afraid of death.
None does not fear the pain [inflicted with] rods (2).
Just as you would forgive yourself,
Don't kill; don't strike with rods (3).
He who ever cares for the well-being of creatures,
And does not inflict pain on them;
Will meet with no harm in this life,
And be always well happy hereafter (4).
Do not speak harsh words;
He who speaks thus must fear retribution.
Evil being done, disaster will follow,
And knives and rods will come upon your body (5).
Be kind in uttering words,
Like knocking at a gong [gently].
When you dispute no more,
You will transcend existence easily (6).
He who strikes the good ones with sticks,
And vilifies those who are innocent;
Will be retributed ten-fold with misfortune.
Which will befall him promptly and inevitably (7).
[Firstly], severe pain while living (8),
[Secondly], physical injury;
[Thirdly], spontaneous illness;
[Fourthly], mental disorder (9);
[Fifthly], false accusation from others;
[Sixthly], trouble from the magistrate;
[Seventhly], destruction of assets;
[Eighthly], separation from relative (10);
[Ninethly] His houses, and everything therein
Being burnt away by fire;
[Tenthly] Falling into hell at death.
Such are the ten [misfortune] (11).
Though one might go naked or shave one's head,
Or for life put on straw-clothes,
Or bathe oneself [in sacred rivers] [or] squat on rocks,
What use are these for [overcoming] one's doubts (12)?
He who neither strikes, kills nor burns,
Nor seeks to be a winner;
Who loves (13) all living beings,
Will meet with no enmity (14).
If there be a person in the world,
Who knows to be shameful;
He is one being induced to progress, (such a person can be said to tempted to progress CH)
Like a thorough bred being whipped (15).
Like a fine horse when whipped,
Advances far on the path.
Even so a man endowed with fair virtue,
Mental concentration and vigour;
Commits to the Path (16) and accomplishes wisdom (17),
Hereby elimiting all sufferings (18).
He who [though] well adorned practises the dharma (19), (He who is strict with himself so as to cultivate the Law CH)
Who restrains himself (20) and upholds the pure life,
Laying aside the cudgel towards all creatures,
Is said to be a cultivator (21).
He who is harmless towards all creatures,
Will never in his life be harmed.
If he is always kind towards all,
Who is there to be his enemy(22)?

div.head:
老耗品《法句經》第十九十有四章
The chapter on 'Old Age'

p.seg: The chapter on 'Old Age'
aims at persuading us to be diligent.
If we do not struggle with the [fleeting] life,
what is the use of regretting when old?
What's there to rejoice, what's there to laugh?
Life is always in a blaze!
Deeply concealed in Darkness,
It's better to seek light (1). (to rejoice or to laugh is like not looking for a lamp/the lamp of the buddhist truth CH)
Look at this physical body
Which [the fool] clings (2) to as comfort.
It's full of [false] thinking and causes sickness,
How does [the fool] know its unreality (3)?
When one gets old, the body becomes weak,
Sickness befalls and lustre is lost;
The skin slackens, and muscles contract.
One is fast approaching death (4).
When the body dies, consciousness departs,
Like a driver abandoning a vehicle;
The flesh diappears, the bones scatter
What is there in the body to rely on (5)?
The body is like a city,
Framed with bones and plastered with flesh.
From birth till old age and death,
It stores nothing but hatred and conceit (6).
When one gets old, the body changes,
Just like an old vehicle.
The Dharma can end suffering
-practise it with deligence (7).
If a man has heard no [wise teaching]
He will grow old to be a bull:
With only well developed flesh, (only grow so that the flesh becomes fat>abundant CH)
But no wisdom (8).
The cycle of birth and death is boring;
The coming and going is troublesome.
When one's thoughts are attached to the body,
Endless suffering will follow (9).
As the wise perceives suffering,
He accordingly abandons the body;
His thoughts are ceased and conditioning (10) cut off;
And lust being ended, there is no more birth (11).
He who neither practises the Brahma-like faring,
Nor has acquired any wealth;
At old age, is like a white heron
Watching an empty pond (12).
If one neither observes the precepts
Nor accumulates wealth;
When old and weak and panting,
What's the use of reminiscing the past (13)?
At old age, one is like the autumn's leaves;
One moves (14) in filth, and wears tattered clothes (15).
Life is rapidly escaping from this birth;
There is no (17) use to regret (18).
Life is running out as days and nights pass.
Strive hard when there is still time.
What pertains to the world is truly impermanent,
Don't be deluded and fall into darkness (19).
Learn to kindle the mind lamp,
And train yourself to gain wisdom.
Move away from taints, don't fet stained;
Holding the [mind] candle, watch the stages of progress (20).

div.head:
愛身品《法句經》第二十十有三章
The aim of this chapter on 'Self-Concern'lg==

p.seg: The aim of this chapter on 'Self-Concern'
is to advise us to learn
that which will ultimately benefit ourselves,
and help us to get rid of evil and accrue merit.
He who has love for himself (2)
should cautiously protect what is being guarded (3),
He should aspire for the release from craving
And, forgoing sleep, to be rectified (4).
Oneself comes (5) first,
One should (train) hard oneself;
When benefit is derived, then instruct others.
The wise is thus not vexed (7).
First learn to rectify oneself,
Then only rectify others.
Train yourself to enter wisdom,
And you will surely move upwards (8).
If one cannot benefit oneself,
How can one benefit others?
When one's mind is tamed, and body rectified,
What aim is there that cannot be achieved (9).
What has been done by oneself before,
One will experience its effect later.
Having done evil, one [suffers] through oneself,
Like a diamond boring through a gem (10).
If one does not observe the precepts,
[Craving] will spread like a rattan creeper.
One's desires being unrestrained,
Evil actions will increase day by day (11).
Evil actions endanger oneself;
They are easy for the fool.
Good actions are one's best security;
They are difficult for the fool (12).
Those who accord with the True Men's teaching,
And live (13) in accordance with Truth,
The fool envies them,
And views them as evil (14).
Evil actions yield bad [results],
Like the sowing of bitter seeds.
Having done evil, one suffers oneself;
Having done good, one experiences happiness oneself.
And (15) each [result] must ripen [accordingly]
-It cannot be [experienced] on each other's behalf.
[Like-wise], good actions yield good [results],
Like the sowing of sweet seeds (16).
One should benefit oneself as well as others,
And there will be benefit without much effort (17).
If one desires to know how to benefit oneself,
[Here it is]: Precepts and knowledge (18) are the best (19).
One who has love for himself,
And wishes to be born in heavens,
Should, with respect and delight, listen to the Dharma
And remember the Buddha's Teachings (20).
One must think carefully before any undertaking,
So that one's effort would not be spoilt.
Thus one's thinking becomes more and more trained,
And one does not miss the time for any undertaking (21).
One who has his undertaking well prepared,
Can reach the goal and achieve profit.
A true understanding would be put into practice,
And one will thereby achieve one's aim (22).

div.head:
世俗品《法句經》第二十一十有四章
The chapter on 'The world'lg==

p.seg: The chapter on 'The world'
explains that the world is an illusion;
that we should [therefore[ give up the 'floating flowers' -
[the unreal material comfort], and diligently practise the spiritual path.
As a cart travelling on the road,
Which, leaving the level, broad road,
Turns onto a small side road and is crashed
-There is the sorrow of the breaking of the axles (1).
Likewise, leaving the Dharma
To follow and develop that opposed to Dharma,
The fool keeps his way until death
-And there is also the sorrow of being broken (2).
Fare in accordance with Dharma,
Do not accord with evil deed;
The dharma-farer (3) sleeps well,
And there is no sorrow in every existence (4).
All things are like foam,
The mind is like a wild horse;
Living in a world like a mirage,
How can one delight in it (5)?
If one can break away from this,
Cutting the tree its roots,
And persisting thus day and night,
One will surely achieve concentration (6).
Some give in accordance with faith,
Like people who are happy;
Others, from a perturbed mind,
Offer food to the [monk-] community
-Such people, day and night
Achieve no mental concentration (7).
The worldlings have no eyes;
They see not the truth of the Way.
Those with even a little clarity of vision,
Should nurture good thoughts (8).
Like goose heading its group,
To fly high in voidance of the net;
The wise one leads the world,
To get freed from the evil ones (9).
All worldlings must die,
There is no security in the three spheres.
Though the gods may enjoy themselves,
They too die when their merit is exhausted (10).
Observe the worldlings:
No birth does not come to an end.
If one wishes to escape the cycle of rebirth,
One should practise the true Path (11).
Delusion covers up the whole world;
Greed causes the loss of sight.
False [views] (12) and doubt lead to rejecting Truth (13).
-The afflicted fools accord with these (14).
He who has transgressed one dharma,
Namely, the liar,
Will not escape future existence,
And there's is no evil that he will not further (15) do (16).
Though one may pile up treasure,
To as high as the heavens,
Thus filling up the whole world;
It's better to gain insight into th Path (17).
What is not good appears to be good,
Lust appears to be not lust;
Suffering is taken for happiness
-the insane is devoted to (18) [these false views] (19).

div.head: 《法句經》序
述佛品《法句經》第二十二二十有一章

p.seg: The chapter 'On The Buddha's virtues"
explains [the Buddha's] holy virtues
which are always beneficial for salvation;
they are made clear so that they may serve as guiding principles for the world.
Having (1) made the conquest he is not subject to evil (2),
He is completely victorious over the world;
Saintly wise, and of boundless sphere,
[The Buddha] initiates the ignorant into the Path (3).
Disentangled from [craving's] net end unimpeded;
Lust exhausted, with nothing to amass;
The Buddha's mind is profound, without a limit.
He leads those not on the Path to embark on it (4).
Steadfastly established in one-mindedness,
Left home, in quiescence day and night,
Root cut off, with no lustful thoughts
-[Such are] the awakened ones (5), the clearly mindful (6).
He has seen the Thruth, and is pure, undefiled,
Having crossed the sea of the five pathways
-The Buddha- arises, illuminating the world,
In order to remove sufferings (7).
Difficult it it is to be born as a human.
Difficult too the obtaining of longivity for mortals.
Difficult is the arising of Buddhas in the world.
Difficult it is to hear the Buddha-dharma (8).
I had no one for a master (9),
Alone, nor had I any companion.
Accumulating one (10) practice I have become a Buddha.
By myself (11) I have mastered the Noble Path (12).
A boatman can cross over water;
Vigour serves as the bridge.
Men are bound by their casted;
He who can cross over is a hero (13).
Those having destroyed evil and crossed over are the Buddhas.
Those on the land are the brahmins.
Those who remove famine are the Dharma-trainees.
Those who cut off the castle lineage are the disciples (14).
Of mental devotion, endurance is foremost.
'Nirvana is supreme' say the Buddhas.
He who has left home (15) to be a sramana
Does no harm to others (16).
Do not harass by speech or harm;
Restrain fully in accordance with the precepts;
Be moderate in food and give up bodily greed;
Maintain your practice in a secluded abode;
Apply your mind to the gaining of wisdom (17).
-This is practising the Buddhas' teaching.
Not to do evil,
To cultivate all good,
To purify one's own mind,
-This is the Teaching of the Buddhas (19).
[I,] (20) the Buddha am the Exalted One;
[I] have eradicated the cankers and have no lust;
[I] am the hero amongst the Sakyans;
The whole lot [of gods and men] (21) accords with [my] mind (22).
Happy indeed is the result of merit;
Whereby all wishes are fulfilled.
[One with merit] promptly moves to quiescence
And arrives by himself at Nirvana (23).
Many go for refuge
To spirits in hills, rivers and trees,
And to images in shrines;
Offering sacrifices and praying for blessings (24).
Refuges like these
Are neither safe nor supreme.
They cannot come
To deliver us from all unsatisfactoriness (25).
If one goes for refuge
To the Buddha, Dharma and Sangha;
The virtous Four Truths;
One will definitely see [with] Right Knowledge (26):
[Namely], That samsara is extremely unsatisfactory;
That from [seeing] the Truths one crosses over (27).
That the Eight-fold Path which transcends existence,
Eradicates all unsatisfactoriness (28).
Refuge in these Three Treasured Ones,
Is most safe, is supreme;
Only if one has these [refuges]
Can one transcend all unsatisfactoriness (29).
If a man [accord with] the middle and the proper,
And sets his mind on the Way, without miserliness;
Propitious indeed such a man is,
Who goes for refuge in the Buddha (30).
A man of wisdom is hard to encounter,
And he is not to be found everywhere;
Where such a man is born,
The kinsmen are blessed (31).
Happy is the arising of Buddhas.
Happy is the preaching of the Doctrine.
Happy is the unity of the Sangha;
Unity brings constant peace (32).

div.head:
安寧品《法句經》第二十三十有四章
安寧品者， The chapter on 'Happiness' (1)

p.seg: The chapter on 'Happiness' (1)
differentiates between what leads to happiness and what leads to danger.
[It explains that] when one gives up evil and accords with good,
one gains happiness and will not fall.
We (20) already live in happiness,
Hating not amidst the hateful.
While others harbour hatred,
We course without hating (3).
We already live in happiness,
Not falling sick amidst the sick.
While others fall sick,
We course without sickness (4).
We already live in happiness,
Worrying not amidst the worried.
While others have worries,
We course without worrying (5).
We already live in happiness,
Pure, desiring naught (6).
We feed on joy,
Even as the Radiant Devas (7).
We already live in happiness
Living a simple life, contendted.
The fir of Mithila kingdom (8)
-How can it burn us (9)?
Victory begets hatred;
The defeated feels inferior.
Renouncing thoughts of victory and defeat,
One is happy, without combatting (10).
There is no heat like lust,
There is no poison like anger;
There is no misery like the body;
There is no happiness like the quiescence [of Nirvana] (11).
Without being happy with small happiness,
Small eloquence, small intelligence;
He who sets is mind on the big ones,
Will achieve big happiness (12).
I am the World Honoured One
Forever released, sorrowless.
I have perfectly transcended the triple existence;
And alone, defeated the evil ones (13).
Happiness is seeing the holy ones.
Happiness is the association [with them].
Being able to part with fools
Is good and uniquely happy (14).
Happiness is the keeping to the Right Path.
Happiness is the skillful (15). preaching of Dharma.
By not disputing with the world,
And endowed with precepts, one is always happy (16).
Happiness is living with the virtous,
Like [that of] meeting with kinsfolk.
He who draws near to the virtous and wise
will hear much and get far away (17).
Few are those who live long,
And many are those who leave the world.
In one's training one should seze the means
Which gives happiness til old age (18).
For those wishing for the ambrosia,
The cessation Truth- the removal of craving- is bliss.
Those wishing to transcend the suffering of samsara;
Should take the taste of ambrosia (19).

div.head:
好喜品《法句經》第二十四十有二章
The chapter on affection

p.seg: The chapter on affection
aims at teaching us to restrain from over indulgence in affection.
If we can be free from craving,
we shall be without sorrows.
What contravenes the spiritual life (1) one accords with it;
What accords with the spiritual life one contravenes it,
Leaving the real good one grasps at the pleasant
-Such is according with craving (2).
Do not seek to be with the beloved
Nor should one have enbeloved.
The meeting with the beloved is painful;
Meeting with the unbeloved is also painful (3).
Therefore create not any endearment
Affection and hatred originate from evil.
For those who are freed from bonds,
There is neither affection nor hatred (4).
Endearment begets sorrow
Endearment begets fear
For him free from endearment
Whence sorrow, whence fear? (5)
Craving begets sorrow
Craving begets fear
For him liberated, without craving;
Whence sorrow whence fear? (7)
Craving begets sorrow
Craving begets fear
For him liberated, without without craving;
Whence sorrow whence fear? (7)
He who desires the Dharma, endowed with virtue,
He who is thruthful and shameful,
Who goads himself to be near the Way (8),
Him do people hold dear. (7)
He who externalizes not his desire state,
Who speaks having first rectified his thoughts,
Whose mind is free from lust'
Will stop the stream and cross over (10).
As one who has gone on a long journey,
And returns safe from afar;
His kinsfolk are well and happy,
Rejoicing to see him return (11).
Likewise, he who delights to in merit-making,
Having gone from here to there
Will receive the blessing of his merit
Just as kinsmen's rejoicing in his return (12).
Rise up and follow the holy teachings,
Restrain from what is unskilful.
When you meet one close to the Way, devote to him;
Do not get close away from the Way (13).
Those near the way and those not,
Will go (14) to different places:
Those near Way will axcend to heaven;
Those not near will fall into hell (15).

div.head:
忿怒品《法句經》第二十五二十有六章
The purpose of the chapter on "Anger"

p.seg: The purpose of the chapter on "Anger"
is to [make us] see the damages reulting from anger and hatred.
[It explains that] he who is forgiving, kind and gentle,
is beloved of gods and men.
He who is angry sees not the Dharma;
He who is angry knows not the Way (1).
He who can remove anger,
Merit and joy always follow him (2).
He who is lustful sees not the Dharma;
The same for he whose mind is delusion,
He who removes lust and delusion,
His merit stands foremost (3).
He who can refrain from anger,
Like halting a running chariot;
Is indeed a fine charioteer,
Who leaves darkness to enter brightness (4).
Forbearance excels anger (5);
Good excels evil;
The winner (6) is one who gives;
Truthfulness excels deceit (7).
Do not cheat, do not get angry,
Do not seek much in your mind,
He who [can do] these three,
Ascends to heaven at death (8).
Those who are ever restrained in body,
Who are kind and do not kill;
Go to the celestial abodes
And having reached there become sorrowless (9).
Those whose mind is always awake.
Who diligently practice day and night (10);
With their mind determined (11) to end corruptions (12).
They will attain Nirvana.
People blame one another,
From time of old till now.
They blame him of old till now.
They blame him who is reluctant to speak (14),
And him who speaks in moderation;
In the world none is not blamed (15).
One with a craving mind is unlike a noble one,
Not being able to keep to the Middle.
He either blames altogether or praises altogether;
All in order to promote (16) hos own name (17).
He who is praised by the wise,
Is to be regarded as virtous.
Such a man endowed with wisdom and precepts
Is beyond any blame whatsoever (18).
He who is pure as an arahat;
Do not vilify him.
He is praised by gods (19),
As by Brahma and Sakya (20).
Always guard and be cautious of your body,
So as to be restrained from anger (21).
Forsaking evil bodily acts,
Advance in the practice of virtous (22).
Always guard and be cautious of your speech
So as to be restrained from anger (21).
Forsaking evil bodily acts,
Advance in the practice of virtues (22).
Always guard and be cautious of your mind,
So as to be restrained from anger.
Forsaking evil thoughts in the mind,
Meditate and be mindful of the Way (24).
He who is restrained in body and speech
And who controls his mind;
Giving up anger and practising the Way,
Is the strongest in forbearance (25).
Give up anger, renounce conceit
And avoid all lustful cravings (26).
Not clinging to the psycho-physical existence,
And being unattached, one will end suffering (27).
He who removes anger the moment it arises;
He who restrains from lust as it occurs;
He who is heroic in renouncing ignorance;
All these people will find happiness (28).
He who cuts off anger sleeps well,
Hatred ceasing, there is no (29) sorrow.
Anger is the root of all poisons.
A brahmin with a soft mind
And good words will gain fame;
[Anger] removed, there is no worry (30).
He who, together with other like-minded,
Collaborates in evil doing;
Company being parted, is left with anger,
With which fire he torments himself (31).
He who knows no moral fear or shame,
Who observes no precepts and is angry;
Is dragged on by anger
And never gets tired of the toil of existence (32).
The strong goes near [and clash with] the warriors.
Those without strength go near the weak.
[But] endurance is indeed best;
One should always endure the weak (34).
We as much as others,
Have great fear regarding three (35).
If we perceive the [mis-] deeds of others
We should destroy [the fault] (36) within ourselves (37).
We as much as others,
Have great fear regarding three (35).
If we perceive the [mis-] deeds of others
We should destroy [the fault] (36) within ourselves (37).
Do things from the view-points of both:
Ourselves as much as others (38).
If we perceive the [mis-] deeds of others
We should destroy [the faults] within ourselves (39).
The very wise ones excel the fools (40),
Who utter abuse and evil words.
He who wishes to win always,
Should remain silent to (abusive) wors (41).
The doers of evil
Get retribution of anger for their anger,
Those who reciprocate not anger with anger,
Win over those defeated in clashes (42).

div.head:
塵垢品《法句經》第二十六十有九章
-

p.seg: The chapter of 'Taints'
distinguishes between purity and corruption.
In one's training, one should remain pure,
without practising any corruption.
He who while living has done no good,
At death will fall into the evil destinies.
Swiftly he will go with no [rest] in between
And on arriving, he will find no provisions (1).
You should seek wisdom
To light up the mind lamp (2).
Remove taints, don't be defiled;
And you will be rid of the unsatisfactory body (3).
The wise man, gradually,
Slowly and progressively,
Cleanses his mind of stains;
Like a smith refining gold (4).
Evil, arisen in a man's mind
Corrodes his own body,
Even as rust from an iron
Eats away itself (5).
Non-recitation is the taint of words
Nonexertion is the taint of the home
Non-adornment is the taint of beauty
Heedlessness is the taint of work (6).
Avarice is the taint of giving
Unskillfulness is the taint of action,
Both in this life and in the next,
Evil dharmas always constitute taints (7).
The taint of all taints
Is ignorance, the worst.
Train to give up evil,
O bhiksus! and be taintless (8).
An easy life is one without shame,
Like a crow with a long beak
Which brazenly bears dishonour.
-Such is a life of defilement (9).
A shameful person, though life be hard,
Takes righteously, [remaining] cleanly [of life].
He shuns dishonour and recklessness.
Such is a life of purity (10).
A fool is one indulging in killing,
In speaking untruth,
In taking what is not given,
In trespassing on other's wives (11).
In conscious moral transgressions
In getting addicted to intoxication drinks
Such a man, in every life
Digs up his own rood (12).
Understand thus, O man
Do not contemplate on evil;
A fool who draws near to wickedness
Will for long get himself burnt (13).
People give either out of faith
Or in order to get fame.
If one covets (14) others' worthless ornaments,
One will not attain pure concentration (16).
If one completely removes covetousness,
Cutting off the [craving] mind by the root,
And remains one-minded day and night,
One is sure to attain mental concentration.
Sensual attachment (17) constitutes a taint;
From defilement, there is the corruption (18) of taints
Not getting defiled, nor coursing [in sensual attachment]
One is sure to attain mental concentration (16).
Seeing others corroding themselves,
One should always reflect within:
Corruption in practice is self-humiliation;
Corruptions having ended, there is no taint (20).
There is no fire hotter than lust.
There is no speed greater than anger.
There is no net denser than delusion.
The craving stream is more rapid than a river (21).
There is no track in the sky
There is no outside thought for a sramana
Men all delight in evil (22)
Only the Buddha is pure, without defilement (23).
There is no track in the sky.
There are no outside thoughts for a sramana.
In the world nothing has permanence.
For the Buddha, there is naught of the self (24).

div.head:
奉持品《法句經》第二十七十有七章
The chapter on the 'Spiritually Committed'

p.seg: The chapter on the 'Spiritually Committed'
explains what moral principles are.
In Dharma, moral virtues are valued,
and there is no place for greed.
He who is committed to the spiritual path (2)
Does not compete for profits.
Regarding the profitable and the unprofitable,
He is desireless and undeluded (3).
He who is ever kind and ready to learn,
Who courses with a righteous mind
Embracing the precious [Dharma] at heart, wise;
Is indeed one cultivating the path (4).
One becomes a wise one
Not necessarily by arguing much.
He who is secure and fearless
And guards his goodness, is indeed wise (5).
One is an upholder of the Dharma
Not simply by speaking much.
He who, though not having heard much
Puts the Dharma into practice himself
And who forgets not the Teaching (6)
May be called a Dharma upholder (7).
One becomes an elder
Not simply by being old,
With ripened body and grey hairs.
Such a person [can] be just a fool (8).
He who in whom are thruth, Dharma,
Restraint and kindness;
Who is wise (9) and pure,
Is indeed and Elder (10).
One becomes gracefull (11)
Not having flower-like complexion (12)
While being miserly, jealus and deceitful,
And acting contrary to is words (13).
He who can renounce evil
Having cut it off by its root,
Who is wise and hatred-free
Is said to be graceful (14).
One becomes a sramana
Not merely by shaving one's head
While still telling lies and coveting,
Full of desires like the ordinary people (15).
He who can stop doing evil
Who generously propagates the Teaching
Who stills his mind and thoughts
Is indeed a sramana (16).
One becomes a bhiksu
Not merely by begging at times
While having evil acts and sexual indulgence
This is bhiksu by name only (17).
He who abandoning both merit and demerit
Leads the pure spiritual life
Who is wise and banishes evil,
Is indeed a bhiksu (18).
One becomes a sage
Not by [mere] silence,
Having impure intentions within
And pretending externally (19).
One is said to spiritually advanced (21)
Not [simply] by saving one life
He who strives for universal salvation,
Harmless, is indeed spiritually advanced (22).
Do not boast of your observances,
[Or that] "My actions are mostly truthful" (23).
[Or that] "I have attained mental concentration
By resorting to solitude."
Be determined to seek happiness;
Don't learn from the ordinary worldlings.
So long as your corruptions are not extinct
You will not be liberated (25).

div.head:
道行品《法句經》第二十八二十有八章
The purpose of this chapter on 'The Path'

p.seg: The purpose of this chapter on 'The Path'
is to explain in essential
the way to emancipation,
which is the most wonderful.
The best of paths is the eight-fold right [path]
Four-Truths are the track of Dharma (1)
The best of practices is the giving up of lust.
The giving of lamps (2) ensures the obtaining of eyes (3)
This is the Path, there is no more fear; (4).
When views are purified, ome will transcend existence,
This [Path can crush Mara's army;
Walk on with effort to end suffering (5)
I have already opened up the Right Path,
To fully display the unique splendour.
Having heard it you must train yourself;
Treading it leads to release from the evil bonds (6)
Phenomenal existence (7) is permanent and unsatisfactory;
He who sees this is wise a wise one.
One wishing to be freed from unsatisfactoriness,
Has only tread the Path with diligence (9)
Phenomminal existence (7) is impermanet and usatisfactory;
He who sees this is a wise one.
One wishing to be freed from unsatisfactoriness,
Has only to tread the Path with diligence (9)
One should get up when it's time (10) to do so
Don't be like the fools drowned in deep water,
Who assemble with the lazy (11) and indiffernet, (12)
And feel too tired to advance on the Path (13)
Mindfulness of that to be mindful of is right,
Mindfulness of that not to be mindful of is wrong.
Be wise and do't give rise to wrong [thoughts]
Thoughts being rectified, the Goal will be reached (14)
Cautious in speech and watchful of the mind,
And doing no bodily act which is unskillful
-He who thus removes the threefold [unskillful] deeds,
The Buddha declares, has achieved the Goal (15)
If the tree is cut without being uprooted;
The root still remaining, it will grow again.
Remove the root, then there will be no tree,
And the bhiksu will gain Nirvana (16)
So long as one cannot cut down the trees;
There being mutual attachment between relations, (17)
One binds oneself with the greedy mind
Like a calf after [the mother's] milk (18)
He who can cut off the root of craving (10)
[The root of] the endless cycle of rebirths, (20)
Is said to near the Way (21)
And will soon attain Nirvana (22)
Lust results in ageing;
Hatred in sickness;
Delusion results in death;
The three removed, one will reach the Goal. (23)
Released at the beginning, released at the end,
Released in the middle-one crosses to the other [shore].
All thoughts having been extinguished,
There will be no more old-age and death (24)
To one entangled with wife and sons,
Not contemplating on the ill [natur of] dharmas,
Death will come abruptly,
Like the rapid flow of flood water (25)
Neither father nor son can save,
What hope then from other kinsmen?
To lean for support from kinsmen at life's end,
Is like a blind relying on a lamp (26).
The wise who understands this meaning,
Should put into practice the sutra and vinaya (27)
Practising diligently to transcend the world,
And unsatisfactoriness will be completely removed. (28)
Get far away from the deep-water
Like the wind banishing the clouds
All conceptions having ceased;
It is said to be the vision of wisdom (29)
Wisdom is the world's foremost;
[With it] one contentedly delights in the unconditioned,
And knows (30) the true teachings,
Bringing an end to birth and death (31)
He who knows the conditioning to be unsatisfactory
-This is seeing with wisdom-
Becomes disgusted with worldly unsatisfactoriness;
And from this Path [unsatisfactoriness] is removed (33)
He who knows the conditioning to be unsatisfactory
-This is seeing with wisdom-
Becomes disgusted with worldly unsatisfactoriness;
And from this Path [unsatisfactoriness] is removed (33)
He who knows the conditioning to be unsatisfactory
-This is seeing with wisdom-
Becomes disgusted with worldly unsatisfactorness;
And from this Path [unsatisfactoriness] is removed. (34)
I expounded to you the Dharma,
Having [myself once] been shot with the arrows of craving (35)
You should endeavour yourself
And accept the Tathagata's word (36)
I am one who have completely destroeyed [the defilement]
And ended the coming and going - birth and death.
It is for the liberation of not [just] one single being,
What has been expounded, the Path-eye. (37)
Just as the rivers flow into the sea,
And the water in turn flows on to quickly fill up (38).
Therefore is [the Path] taught to the wise,
By which they can be led to taking the amrata. (39)
The hitherto unheard of dharma-wheel
[The Buddha] turned, out of compassion for beings.
Thoses who devote themselves to Him
Salute Him, and transend the triple existence. (40)
Three thoughts (41) are to be cultivated; being skillful
Three also are to be removed; (42) being unskillful.
From thoughts, there arises actions;
These ceased, it is called true abandonment (43)
Three meditations can transform thoughts (44).
Give up attachment and practise the immeasureable.
Attaining these three, three dens are removed. (45)
To be freed from the fetters, be mindful (46)
He who knows to restrain from evil with the preceps,
Contemplative and wise, delighting in mindfulness,
Has understood the arising and perishing of the world,
His thoughts having ceased, he is liberated from all. (47)

div.head:
廣衍品《法句經》第二十九十有四章
The chapter on 'Spreading Extensively'

p.seg: The chapter on 'Spreading Extensively'
explains that all good and evil,
however small, will accumulate to become greater and greater.
It consists of stanzas conducive to spiritual realization.
Though the happiness in giving may be small
Its retribution is very great.
The wise one, from a small giving,
Sees in retribution, a great blessing (2).
He who be causing hardship to others
Seeks to gain blessing
Misfortune will befall him,
Having himself befriended enemies widely (3).
For one has done various things,
Including the improper ones,
And is sporty and heedless;
His corruptions increase day by day (4).
He who vigorously practises meditation,
Who pursues the proper and gives up the improper,
Who cultivates himself and is mindful,
Is indeed one endowed with the right practice (5).
For one who being inintelligent,
Is moreover keen to learn;
[His knowledge] will gradually expand,
like ghee when thrown into water (6).
For one being unintelligent,
Is moreover not keen to learn;
His knowledge will contract and get less,
Like curd when thrown into water (7).
The names of the spiritual cultivators shine forth
Like snow on high mountains.
Those with no spirituality remain obscure
Like arrows shot at night (10).
The disciples of the Buddha,
Are ever awake and self-aware.
Day and night they recollect the Buddha,
Reflect on the Dharma, and are mindful of the Sangha (11)
The disciples of the Buddha
Are ever (12) awake and self-aware.
Day and night they think of meditating,
And delight in contemplation and one-mindedness (13).
One should maintain mindfulness
And know the amount (14) to eat
One's sensual craving (15) is then reduced
And digestion being regulated, one lives long (16).
Hard it is to undergo training and give up evil.
Har too it is to live the household life.
Hard [also] is living and sharing with others.
Of all hardships, existence is the greatest (17).
Hard it is for a bhiksu to beg [for alms]
How then can you not spur yourself on?
With vigour, you'll obtain ease
And hereafter (18) you'll not covet other's [things] (19).
He who has faith (20) will be endowed with virtue;
From virtue, he will attain wealth;
From the same will he obtain a happy partner;
Wherever he goes, he recieves offerings (21).
He who sits alone, rests in one place (22),
Walks alone, unindolent,
And keeping to solitude rectifies the self;
Will delight in forest dwelling (23).

div.head:
地獄品《法句經》第三十十有六章
The chapter on 'The Hells'

p.seg: The chapter on 'The Hells'
explains what happens in the hells:
He who commits evil will experience evil retribution.
His evil will drag him along, without letting go.
The liar approaches hell,
[Also] he who having done something says he hasn't.
Both these offenders hereafter will suffer alike,
Having dragged themselves there with such actions (1).
Those who donning the robes;
commit evil, and are unrestrained;
Such base evil doers,
At death will fall into hells (2).
If one, being immoral, accepts offerings,
Would he not be harming himself?
At death he will swallow red-hot iron balls,
And be burnt by flaring charcoals (3).
Four things beset the heedless man
Who is fond of committing adultery;
[First] bad sleep, [second] demerit,
Third ill-repute, and fourth sensual indulgence (4).
There being demerit, he will have bad rebirth.
The fearful [man] and fearful (5) [woman] enjoy but little.
The king imposes heavy punishment on them.
And at death they go to hell (6).
Just as in the uprooting of wild grasses (7);
If not grabbed properly, they cut the hamd.
In ethical training, if there be faults,
One is picked for hell one's own making (8).
In the ordinary man's faring, if there be slackness,
It cannot lead to the removal of hardship.
In the spiritual faring, if there be faults,
It will never yield great blessing (10).
Always do what you ought to do,
Persevere and make your practice strong.
Seperate yourself from the heretics;
Don't be influenced and tainted (11).
If one does what ought not to be done,
One will later be poisoned with depression.
If one does good one will always be well,
And wherever one is, one has no remorse (12).
He who with regard to an evil deed,
Intends to do or has already done;
Cannot be freed from the ensuing suffering:
Evil retribution nearing, he finds no escape (13).
He who gives false evidence to get bribes;
He who himself having behaved improperly,
Malign the good ones out of hatred;
He who treats the learned unjustly;
-Such people, bound by their evil,
Throw themselves into pits (14).
Like a guarded border city;
Firm within and without.
So guard your own mind,
[Let] no evil thought (15) arises.
Lapses in action beget grief;
And will lead you to hell (16).
Those unashamed of what is shameful,
And ashamed of what is not shameful;
-Such beings, holding false views,
Go to hell at death (17).
Those unafraid of what is not fearful,
And afraid of what is not fearful;
-Such beings, disposed towards false views;
Go to hell at death (19).
Those who approach what should be shunned,
And don't approach what should be approached;
-Such beings, addicted to false views,
Go to hell at death (19).

div.head:
象喻品《法句經》第三十一十有八章
The chapter on 'The Elephant Simile'

p.seg: The chapter on 'The Elephant Simile'
teaches men to rectify themselves.
Those who do good will receive good;
the retribution of their merits comes promptly.
I, like the elephant in battle
Unafraid of being struck by arrows,
Ever with sincere faith
Transform those without virtues. (1)
Just as a properly trained elephant
Is fit for the king to ride on;
One who is trained is exalted among men
And fit to be believed in. (2)
Even those as properly tamed,
As the through-bred horses of Sinh,
And the best elephants;
Cannot excel a man who has tamed himself (3)
Those [untrained men] (4) cannot go
To places where men have not been
Only those who have subdued themselves
Can go to the place of the subdued (15)
Like an elephant named Dhanapalaka,
Who is ferocious and hard to restrain;
Though chained and not given food
It still remains wild as a ruttled elephant. (6)
Those immersed in evil actions,
Ever have themselves chained by greed;
Like the elephant which is unsatiable,
And thus repeatedly enter into the womb. (7)
Formerly, the mind has been drifting aimlessly,
And always going where it finds pleasure.
[Now, I] (8)shall give it all up and subdue passions,
Like a mahout subduing an elephant with hooks. (9)
He who delights in the Path and is heedful (10),
Who can constantly protect his mind
Is one who lifts himself out of suffering;
Like an elephant getting out of a trap. (11)
If you get a capable companion
Who would move with you, and is firm in doing good;
You will defeat all the famous (12)
And remain mindful having attained your goal. (14)
If you don't get a capable companion
Who would move with you and is firm in doing good;
Then dissociate from all, [like] a king his lands.
It's better to be alone without doing evil. (16)
It's better to move alone, doing good;
And not befriend the fools.
Be alone and do no evil,
Like a frightened elephant protecting itself (17).
Happiness is to be born with wealth.
Happiness is to have gentle and agreeable friends.
Happiness is having merit at life's end.
Happiness is not committing any evil (18).
Happiness is having a mother in the family.
Happiness too is having a father.
Happiness is the existence of sramanas in the world.
Happiness is the existence of the Way in the world (19).
Happiness is practising virtue till old age.
Good is when one's faith is pure where it should be pure.
Wisdom delights oneself most
The greatest is not doing evil.
Just as a horse that is properly trained,
Goes according to the tamer's wish;
One endowed with faith, virtue, vigour,
Concentration and examination of dharmas,
Who is established in knowledge and conduct (21),
Who has patience and mental stability,
Will get rid of all suffering,
In accordance with his wish (22).
From this, one will go into concentration (23),
Like a horse having been tamed,
One is freed from anger and the corruptions,
And experiences the bliss of gods. (24)
He who is not heedless
Will thereby become more wakeful,
Like a nag compared to a fine horse:
He who gives up evil is the better (25).

div.head:
愛欲品《法句經》第三十二三十有二章
The chapter on 'Craving'

p.seg: The chapter on 'Craving'
deals with lowly sexual indulgence and passionate love,
as a result of which the worldly people
incur much harm for themselves.
If one's mind is set onn sexual activities,
One's craving increases, like [a creeper's] brances
Spreading and growing ever more luxuriantly;
And one keeps leaping, like a monkey greedy for fruits (1).
One who for the sake of lust endures sorrow,
Who owing to craving is attached to the world;
His sorrow increases day and night,
Growing and spreading like a vine (2).
Men are deluded because of passionate love;
They are unable to give up passions.
Thus do sorrow and passionate love increase,
Like flowing water filling up a pond (3).
That there are sorrow, grief,
And suffering in the world, of not [just] one kind,
Is due to none but craving.
Craving ceasing, there is no sorrow (4).
One's own mind being at peace, craving (5) is abandoned,
Without craving, where is the world?
Not grieving, nor seeking with defilement.
Nor craving; whence is the world (6)?
Some grieve because at the time of death.
They want many kinsfolks to gather.
Traversing a long journey of sorrow;
They crave and suffer, always falling into distress. (8)
One devoted to the life
Must not befriend craving.
First cut off the root of craving,
So that it can no more take root.
Don't be like cutting reeds;
lest the craving would arise again (9).
Like tree with deep and firm root,
Though cut down grows yet again;
Craving thoughts not completely removed,
One should expect further suffering (10).
Like a monkey, having left behind the trees,
Returns to the trees having been freed (11);
Even so do people in the world,
Get out of hells only to return to hells. (12)
Greedy thoughts constitute an incessant flow,
Which habitually joins force with conceit.
When one's thoughts are inclined to lust,
One conceals oneself, and sees nothing (13).
All thoughts flow and spread;
The craving-fetter is like a rattan creeper.
The wise alone can discern with discrimination,
And cut off the source of [craving] thoughts.
Nourished by craving,
One's thougths grow and spread.
Craving is deep and fathomless,
Adding strength to old-age and death.
The tributaries (16) produced are incessant,
Feeding on craving alone.
To nourish enemies and multiply graves,
The fools are ever restlessly striving (17).
Though in prison, there are hooks and chains,
Deep, strong, and difficult to escape.
Threfore should it be cut and abandoned;
Not bothered (20) with desire, one is happy (21). SEE NOTES
The wise say that craving is a prison,
Deep, strong, and difficult to escape.
Therefore should it be cut and abandoned;
Not bothered (20) with desire, one is happy.
At the sight of a female, he is tempted,
Not meditating on impermanence.
The fool thinks [of her] as beautiful
-How does he know its unreality (22)?
[The fool] envelopes himself with sexual pleasure,
Like the sikworms making their cocoons.
The wise can give it up,
And not being bothered by it, end all sufferings (23).
One whose mind is bent on heedlessness,
Views sexual indulgence as being pure;
His thoughts of passionate love being intensified,
He thus creates a prison (24).
He whose thoughts cease in sexual craving,
Is ever mindful of craving as impure.
Thus does he leave the prison of evil,
And end the problem of old age and death (25).
[The fool] entangles himself with craving's net,
And gets himself covered up by lust's lust.
Being self-indulgent, he is imprisoned;
Like a fish entering a trap (26).
Old-age and death await their chance
Like calves wanting their mother's milk.
Craving abandoned and lust's tracks obliterated,
[The wise] leaves the net disentangled (27).
He who has completed the Way, freed from prison,
Understanding all from one [end] to the other (28);
Has transcended the practice of extremity.
Such a man is a great wise one (29).
Don't be close to those remote from the Dharma,
Don't be stained (30) by lust either.
He who has not cut off the three times,
Will fall again into practice of extremity (31).
If one is awakened to [the true nature of] all dharmas,
One will then not be attached to the dharmas;
Having been freed from all thoughts of lust,
One is said to have mastered the sages' thoughts (32).
Of all gifts, the gift of Buddha's discourses (33) excels.
Of all flavours, the flavour of Truth (34) excels.
Of all bliss, the bliss of Dharma excels.
The exhaustion of lust excels all sufferings (35).
The fool binds himself with greed,
And seeks not to cross over to the other shore.
Owing to greed for wealth and lust (36),
He kills (37) others as well as himself (38).
The craving mind is the field;
Lust, hatred and delusion are the seeds.
Thus giving to those having transcended the world,
One gains immeasurable amount of merit (30).
With a few companions but plenty of goods,
A merchant trembles with fear.
Craving is a robber that kills,
Therefore the wise do not crave (40).
Where the mind agrees, there craving is.
-Why then only the five-fold craving?
The agreement defied and the five-fold craving cut,
One becomes a hero indeed (41).
Where there is no craving, there is no fear;
Where there is contentment there is no sorrow.
When craving is removed and fetters undone,
One is said to be far out from the sea (42).
O craving! I know your fount:
You are born of thoughts in the mind.
The moment I cease thinking of you,
You will exist no more (43).
In cutting trees [of craving], don't stop.
So long as the tree grow, there will be evil,
When each and every tree is cut,
The bhiksu will attain Nirvana (44).
If the trees [of craving] are not cut
- Even if there be a tiny bit of passion remaining,
The mind will get hung up there
Like the calves wanting [milk from] the mother (45).

div.head: 利養品《法句經》第三十三有二十章

沙門品《法句經》第三十四三十有二章
The chapter on 'the Sramana'

p.seg: The chapter on 'the Sramana'
consists of exhortations of proper Dharma,
which, when the disciple practises accordingly,
will lead to the goal of libaration and purification.
Upright with regard to eye, ear, nose and mouth,
And ever restrained in body and mind;
A bhiksu who practises thus
Can be free from all suffering (1).
Transgress not with hand or foot (2)
restrain speech and be cautious in action
Always delight in meditation within,
Practise solitude (3) and be silent (4).
Learn to be controlled in tongue,
Moderate in speed (5), and not excited (6),
Bound (7) to [expounding] the meaning and Dharma (8);
Make sure to be gentle in speech (9).
6ne who is fond of the Dharma, delight in the Dharma,
Ponders over and confides in Dharma,
-Such a bhiksu, following the Dharma,
Is upright [in the Dharma], and wastes no effort (10).
In training one should not seek gain (11),
Nor should one course coveting others.
A bhiksu who covets others,
Cannot attain to concentration (12).
A bhisu who seeks little,
And accumulates not with what he gets (13)
Is praised by gods and men,
Having a pure life, untainted (14).
A bhiksu who practises kindness,
Who loves and respects the Buddha's Teaching,
Who is deep into concentration and insight (15);
Attains happiness when the conditionings (16) cease (17).
All mental and physical objects
Are unreal; don't be deluded.
He who grieves not when they are not near,
Is truly a bhiksu (19).
Bhiksu! bail water out from the boat!
When empty within, it becomes light.
When greed, hatred and ignorance are removed,
This is Nirvana (20).
Abandon five, cut off five (21),
And meditate on the five faculties (22).
He who can analyzes the five [fetters]
Thereby crosses over the river (23).
Meditate without being heedless.
Do not let desires disperse [your mind].
Do not swallow a [red-hot] copper,
And then be vexed at the body being burnt (24).
There is no meditation (25) for one without wisdom;
No wisdom for one without meditation.
Enlightenment (26) is born of meditation and wisdom;
[With them] one can reach Nirvana (27).
One should (28) learn to enter into empty;
Go into retreat to calm the mind;
Delight in solitude;
And one-mindedly contemplate on the Dharma (29).
One should subdue the five skandhas;
And overcome the mind to be like water (30),
Peaceful and calm,
-This is the taste of ambrosia (31).
He who accepts not what he [already] has,
-This is a wise bhiksu.
He is controlled in the sense, and content,
And observes all the disciplinary rules (32).
Let his life be pure in conduct;
Let him seek spiritual friends;
Let the wise fulfil others' [need];
[Thereby] transcending suffering to find bliss (33).
Just like Jasmine flowers (34),
Which fall of themselves on withering;
When greed, hatred, and ignorance are removed,
Transmigration is automatically transcended (35).
Calm in body, and speech,
Mind ever remaining quiescent;
A bhiksu who loathes the worldly
Is said to have experienced tranquillity (36).
One should command one's body (37),
And within, struggle with one's mind.
Guarding his body and mindful of the Truth,
A bhiksu lives happily (38).
One is one's own Self.
The no-existent being reckoned [as real], the self exists.
Therefore subdue (39) the self;
When tamed it will be like a fine [horse] (40).
[A bhiksu] joyful in the Buddha's teaching,
